awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Examination of Behavioral and Biological Change in an Extended Chronological Context
awd_abstract_narration:
Drs. Jackson Njau of the Indiana University, Bloomington and Lindsay McHenry of University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, along with colleagues from the US, Europe, and Tanzania, seek to understand the relationships between Earth system history and human ("hominin") evolution by investigating the environmental contexts in which early ancestors of humans evolved. Previous researchers have postulated that climate-driven environmental changes on the African continent strongly influenced such evolution over the last several million years. Whether (and how) humans and other species adapt to changing climate is a scientific subject that has captivated public interest. Archaeology is well placed to link climate and environmental history to hominin records by integrating paleoenvironmental datasets archived in the sediments of ancient lakes near paleoanthropological sites. In addition to generating new scientific data, this project will open new interdisciplinary research frontiers across the earth sciences and anthropology that will impact the scientific debates on human origins research. 

The team will investigate how and when climate and environmental forces influenced adaptation during the critical times of human evolution. Do changes in morphology, innovation, sociality, and behavioral traits reflect changes in the local ecology, such as habitat, food, predation pressure, and the availability of resources on the landscape? These questions will be addressed by linking the detailed paleoclimatic record recovered from drilled sediment cores to excavated archeological sites. Four recently acquired cores from the ancient lake at Olduvai Gorge, Tanzania, covering over 2 million years of sedimentation, will be compared to key nearby archeological layers that document records of evolving hominin species and changes in stone tool technologies. Lake sediments archive climate history through time, therefore providing an unprecedented paleoclimatic record of the paleoanthropological material from the prehistoric Olduvai lake basin. These paleoenvironmental data will inform models of hominin land use behaviors and elucidate how climatic change drove hominin adaptations in morphology and cultural behaviors that allowed them to better adapt to variable environmental conditions. Using the composition of volcanic ash layers and detailed examination of the sedimentary units preserved in both cores and outcrops, the team will examine whether times of significant environmental change (as determined in the cores) correspond to times of significant cultural or biological change (in the outcrops and excavations). This project will provide research opportunities and training to a diverse group of American and Tanzanian scholars, provide educational outreach opportunities, and foster international collaboration and understanding.

por.por_cntn:
A major question in the study of human prehistory is whether, how, and to what degree the evolution of hominin species, the development of stone tool technologies, and other cultural, behavioral, and migration developments over the last two million years was affected by changes in environment (and on the grander scale, climate). To address this question, the Olduvai Gorge Coring Project (OGCP) recovered four sediment cores from three sites targeting the ancient lake that once occupied the Olduvai basin (Tanzania, East Africa), measuring a cumulative 600 meters with the longest core reaching ~245 meters below the surface and an age of 2.24 million year. These cores were drilled within several kilometers of the famous Olduvai Gorge paleoanthropological sites, which have yielded an extensive and well-studied record of hominin species and stone tool technologies.

The current study developed much-needed links between the cores (which document the environmental conditions in the lake) and the outcrops in which the hominin record is preserved, using the composition of individual volcanic ash layers found in the four cores and in outcrop. For Olduvai Bed I, all major volcanic ash layers previously known in outcrop were identified in one or more of the cores, providing the tie-lines necessary to relate the environmental proxy records from the lake cores to evolutionary trends observed in the Olduvai paleoanthropological record for this important interval (~2.03 - 1.8 Ma). These volcanic ash identifications also informed the age model for the cores, which establishes the relationship between depth in core and the age of the deposits.

This study also characterized the mineralogy and geochemical composition of an older series of ashes and other types of volcanic deposit derived from neighboring Ngorongoro volcano, which were not previously known from outcrop and which at present are only known from these cores. This record fills in gaps of our knowledge of the eruptive history of this major volcano, the hazards it likely presented to hominins at that time, and how its eruptions affected the size and location of the Olduvai paleolake.

Finally, this study analyzed the mineralogy of the lake sediments from three of the cores, using X-ray Diffraction of samples collected systematically at 32-cm intervals for the finer-grained portions of the cores. This record shows changes in the minerals that form within the lake (?authigenic? minerals), which vary depending on the pH and salinity of the lake water, which in turn indicate whether the lake was more dried up (and therefore saltier) or larger (and therefore fresher). In particular, changes in the zeolite mineral assemblage (and the presence or absence of authigenic K-feldspar) can serve as proxies for wetter and dried intervals. Within the lake deposits for Olduvai Beds I and lower Bed II, cyclical fluctuations in these mineral assemblages track changes observed in other environmental proxies (such as biomarkers and total organic carbon, reported elsewhere) and can be linked to global climate fluctuations. This study also reveals that paleolake Olduvai was present for far longer than anticipated based on outcrops, and that the older lake was fresher than the Olduvai Bed I and II lake. This ancient lake could have provided a better resource for fresh water for hominins and other animals during the earlier history of the basin.

Broader impact: This highly interdisciplinary study can serve as a model for integrating geological, geophysical, biochemical, and paleoanthropological data to address fundamental questions in paleoanthropology. This study provided training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and the overall OGCP project has had a positive impact on the development of local capacity and paleoanthropological infrastructure in Tanzania. We have engaged local community in the project by involving local people in the field research through collaborations including conservation and protection of paleoanthropological resources, sites, and onsite museums.
